occurrences.line_text: Or gard her to defend from bold oppressors might.
From that first flaw him selfe right well defended.
Gainst whom she saw no meanes to be defended,
But the bold Prince defended him so well,
Was by the Captaine all this while defended:
Defending Ladies cause, and Orphans right,
Defends him selfe, and saues his gotten pray.
I will deferre the end vntill another tide.
The third nor strong nor wise, but spightfullest Defetto.
But most of all Defetto him annoyde,
As bidding bold defiance to his foeman neare.
Three times, as in defiance, there he strooke;
To aunswere his defiaunce in the field,
To take defiaunce at a Ladies word
With fowle reprochfull words he boldly him defide.
But he his idle curtesie defide,
And so defide them each, and so defide them both.
And so defide them each, and so defide them both.
Then when he was defide, in coward corner ly.
And his accuser thereuppon defide:
And with reprochfull blasphemy defide,
As if that highest God defie he would;
Loe I defie thee, and here challenge make,
A prowd rebellious Vnicorne defies,
This lucklesse child, whom thus ye see with bloud defild.
Where be ye now, when she is nigh defild
Defil'd the pledge committed to thy trust?
With beastly sin thought her to haue defilde,
With whom in all abuse thou hast thy selfe defilde?
But his sad fathers armes with bloud defilde,
Whom seeing fit, and with no crime defilde,
Breathing out beastly lust her to defile:
And in all shamefull sort him selfe with her defile.
Her filthy parbreake all the place defiled has.
Defiled was, that dreadfull was to vew,
And eke defiled with foule villanie
Assembled were in field, the chalenge to define.
Then this same vertue, that doth right define:
Since I him lately lost, vneath is to define.
By outward shew her inward sence defining.
This Gyant found her, and by force deflowr'd:
For soone comes age, that will her pride deflowre:
And suffred beasts her body to deflowre:
He with his shamefull lust doth first deflowre,
Vile caytiue wretches, ragged, rude, deformd,
Like swine; for so deformd is luxury,
Is woxen so deform'd, that he has quight
With heary glib deform'd, and meiger face,
And all his face deform'd with infamie,
That who so kild that monster most deforme,
And greedy Rosmarines with visages deforme.
And gentle sprite deforme with rude rusticity.
And soyle which did deforme their liuely hew;
Straunge horrour, to deforme his griesly shade;
Deformed monsters, fowle, and blacke as inke,
Then cride she out, Fye, fye, deformed wight,
Deformed creature, on a filthie swyne,
His three deformed heads did lay along,
They both deformed, scarsely could be known.
Stroke one of those deformed heads so sore,
And wondred at so fowle deformed wight.
Dismayd with that deformed dismall sight,
The vgly vew of his deformed crimes,
And him in bloud and durt deformed quight.
Deformed creatures, horrible in sight,
Deformed creatures, in straunge difference,
And more deformed Monsters thousand fold,
With bloud deformed, lay in deadly swownd:
With matchlesse eares deformed and distort,
Much more deformed fearefull vgly were,
Bearing his sixe deformed heads on hye,
With fearefull shadowes of deformed night,
Whom like disguize no lesse deformed had,
A dreadfull feend, with fowle deformed looke,
Then downe to ground fell that deformed Masse,
All dreadfull pourtraicts of deformitee:
Doth dim with horrour and deformitie,
Much like in foulnesse and deformity
In sad misfortunes foule deformity,
Ah dearest God me graunt, I dead be not defould.
Defowled, and their Lady dresse his wownd,
Which by default I haue not yet defraide.
Vnwares defrauded his intended destiny.
Thou biddest me to eeke? Can Night defray
Till Arthur all that reckoning did defray;
That nought but dire reuenge his anger mote defray.
Till to the brim I haue it full defrayd:
That a proud Amazon did late defy
A bold defyance, did of him requere
She to her vse returnd, and streight defyde
Loathed of ladies all, and of all knights defyde.
Let me this craue, sith first I was defyde,
And turne thee soone to him, of whom thou art defyde.
Who scornes thy ydle scoffe, and bids thee be defyde.
The dastard, that did heare him selfe defyde,
And oft complayn'd of fate, and Fortune oft defyde.
Foule womanwronger, for he him defyde.
Foole (said the Pagan) I thy gift defye,
She daily told, her loue he did defye,
Art thou the caytiue, that defyest me,
Defyld those sacred waues, it rightly hot
Altars defyl'd, and holy things defast,
Where none may be with her lewd parts defyled,
And not in outward shows, but inward thoughts defynd.
They into that ere long will be degendered.
Both day and night, of each degree and place,
With natures pen, in ages graue degree,
In fowle reproch of knighthoods faire degree,
That him againe lou'd in the least degree:
To draw thy dayes forth to their last degree?
And knew his good to all of each degree,
That from the first vnto the last degree,
In chiefe degree are heaped vp on hye:
Eftsoones to court he cast t'auaunce his first degree.
For he despysd to tread in dew degree,
To loue a Ladie faire of great degree,
And that it was a groome of base degree,
Disguised like that groome of base degree,
Some thought to raise themselues to high degree,
And vnto all that liue in high degree,
Exceeding much the state of meane degree,
A Faerie was, yborne of high degree,
The third a Damzell was of low degree,
Thus marched these sixe couples forth in faire degree.
And dayly more offensiue vnto each degree.
That made them dearely lou'd of each degree;
That had done outrage in so high degree:
Daughter vnto a Lord of high degree;
Yet was he but a Squire of low degree;
But for his meane degree might not aspire
This louely swaine the Squire of low degree;
And told his Dame, her Squire of low degree
The Squire of low degree releast
Amongst the rest, that Squire of low degree
But sooth is said, and tride in each degree,
Might match with this by many a degree:
Though I them all according their degree,
And is the Virgin, sixt in her degree,
But like a little Mount of small degree;
They passing by, were guyded by degree
To all of each degree, as doth behoue?
Vpon him tooke the roiall high degree,
Of what degree and what race he is growne.
And courteous withall, becomming her degree.
Who from the high degree of happy state,
From pitch of higher place, vnto this low degree.
But differing in honour and degree:
They teach vs, how to each degree and kynde
Excelling much the meane of her degree;
And rageth sore in each degree and state;
Till that by dew degrees and long pretence,
For by degrees they all were disagreed;
According their degrees disposed well.
In Deheubarth that now South-wales is hight,
Wherefore if me thou deigne to serue and sew,
Which that she may the better deigne to heare,
Mongst whom on me she deigned to bestowe
Sith heauen thee deignes to hold in liuing state,
All that is by the working of thy Deitee.
That for his loue refused deitie;
Which were it not, that I am else delaid
But after labours long, and sad delay,
But sparks, seed, drops, and filth do thus delay;
But to delay the heat, least by mischaunce
Till Diamond disdeigning long delay
Of this or that, the time for to delay,
Till time the tempest doe thereof delay
She drew her far, and led with slow delay.
On th'one side he, on th'other sate Delay,
But being in, Delay in close awaite
Some of their losse, some of their loues delay,
That ye will make me Squire without delay,
The which discourse as now I must delay,
Him to haue bound, and thrald without delay;
Of sundry things, as fell, to worke delay;
The hastie heat of his auowd reuenge delayd.
Those dreadfull flames she also found delayd,
That he should neuer leaue, nor be delayd
For all that hetherto hath long delayd
And wearied his life with dull delayes:
With grassie greene of delectable hew,
In daintie delices, and lauish ioyes,
Abounding all with delices most rare,
With all deare delices and rare delights,
And mournefull meed of ioyes delicious:
Led with delight, they thus beguile the way,
With bowres, and beds, and Ladies deare delight:
Them both together laid, to ioy in vaine delight.
And in her selfe-lou'd semblance tooke delight;
But in vaine glorious frayes he litle did delight.
Ne in this new acquaintaunce could delight,
Do chaunt sweet musick, to delight his mind:
So growen great through arrogant delight
What worlds delight, or ioy of liuing speach
Had no delight to treaten of his griefe;
Them to renew, I wote, breeds no delight:
Best musicke breeds delight in loathing eare:
Was neuer hart so rauisht with delight,
All keepe the broad high way, and take delight
But lay as in a dreame of deepe delight,
The doome of iust reuenge, and take delight
Her blisse is all in pleasure and delight,
But poured out in pleasure and delight;
Whilest with delight of that he wisely spake,
And all delight does raigne, much more then this?
But that the foolish man, fild with delight
That I may more delight in thy embracement deare.
For all in bloud and spoile is his delight.
Thus in still waues of deepe delight to wade,
As her fantasticke wit did most delight,
With one sweet drop of sensuall delight:
And said, and did all that mote him delight,
And vaine delight she saw he light did pas,
Faire shields, gay steedes, bright armes be my delight:
Where gentle court and gracious delight
Whenas those knights beheld, with rare delight,
At last quite rauisht with delight, to heare
Beguild thus with delight of nouelties,
Attempred goodly well for health and for delight.
Armed with darts of sensuall delight,
Of that sweet place, yet suffred no delight
Of all that mote delight a daintie eare,
Or greedily depasturing delight:
And her faire eyes sweet smyling in delight,
My senses lulled are in slomber of delight.
That of them cleeped was the Lady of delight.
Some for vntimely ease, some for delight,
And poured forth in sensuall delight,
All my delight on deedes of armes is set,
Their fit disports with faire delight doe chose,
Her dearest sonne, her dearest harts delight.
In other none, but him, she sets delight,
All her delight is set on Marinell;
That greatest Princes liuing it mote well delight.
So my delight is all in ioyfulnesse,
The losse of her deare brood, her deare delight:
Threw forth most dainty odours, & most sweet delight.
And that vile Hag, all were her whole delight
And courtly seruices tooke no delight,
Enough to hold a foole in vaine delight:
And felt in his old courage new delight
To winne her liking vnto his delight:
Depriu'd of kindly ioy and naturall delight.
Which they so much mistooke, they tooke delight
And company at meat, to do them more delight.
The iolly Satyres full of fresh delight,
Wondrous delight it was, there to behould,
A lay of loues delight, with sweet consent:
And the fraile soule in deepe delight nigh dround:
For still he far'd as dauncing in delight,
Now the sweet lodge of loue and deare delight:
Or to them tydings tell, that mote their harts delight.
Was tickled with delight, and iesting sayd;
For Loue is free, and led with selfe delight,
To whom he made great dalliance and delight.
More wise they weend to make of loue delight,
And Priamond on foote had more delight,
They lightly her requit (for small delight
The eyes of all, allur'd with close delight,
Then would he laugh aloud, and gather great delight.
And made the baite of bestiall delight:
But ah she giuen is to vaine delight,
And walke about her gardens of delight,
That with the sweetnesse of her rare delight,
Druons delight was all in single life,
She is the nourse of pleasure and delight,
That of a fishes shell was wrought with rare delight.
And greedy seas doe in the spoile of life delight.
That of no worldly thing he tooke delight;
Her vertue was the dowre, that did delight.
And gaue them gifts and things of deare delight.
Amongst loose Ladies, lapped in delight:
Where whilest her earthly parts with soft delight
Well solast in that Souldans late delight,
Litae, by him begot in loues delight,
Or change of loue for any worlds delight?
That I nigh rauisht with rare thoughts delight,
For Ladies seruice, and for loues delight,
Mongst which my most delight hath alwaies been,
Whereat Sir Calidore did much delight,
Ioying together in vnblam'd delight,
To solace with his Lady in delight:
And troubled had their quiet loues delight.
With diuers flowres distinct with rare delight,
Him seem'd his feet did fly, and in their speed delight.
Of warres delight, and worlds contentious toyle,
Subdue desire, and bridle loose delight,
For cowardize doth still in villany delight.
In doing gentle deedes with franke delight,
And so would euer liue, and loue her owne delight.
Of beauty gan to bud, and bloosme delight,
For loue in soft delight thereon to rest;
Those daintie parts, the dearlings of delight,
Would neuer more delight in painted show
Deuized to worke delight, was gathered there,
Did spred it selfe, to serue to all delight,
All raunged in a ring, and dauncing in delight.
Those were the Graces, daughters of delight,
And with delight his greedy fancy fed,
That what through wonder, & what through delight,
In much delight, and many ioyes among,
The vile Acrasia, that with vaine delightes,
Full of faire windowes, and delightfull bowres;
And made delightfull musicke all the way,
Suddeinly out of his delightfull dreame
Her to disarme, and with delightfull sport
All that in this delightfull Gardin growes,
And feed her fancy with delightfull chaunge:
The onely pleasant and delightfull place,
Delightfull bowres, to solace louers trew;
Or ought to heare, that mote delightfull bee;
In this delightfull land of Faery,
So downe he sate, and with delightfull pleasure
Layes of sweete loue and youthes delightfull heat:
Delighting all in armes and cruell warre,
In these and like delights of bloudy game
His deare delights were able to annoy:
To slug in slouth and sensuall delights,
And euery of them stroue, with most delights,
With false delights, and fild with pleasures vaine,
And drowne in dissolute delights apart,
Diuerse delights they found them selues to please;
Foolish delights and fond abusions,
Where Pleasure dwelles in sensuall delights,
Which spent their looser daies in lewd delights,
To her delights, she vnto him bewrayd:
Delights in filth and foule incontinence:
And otherwhiles with amorous delights,
And darted forth delights, the which her goodly graced.
The royall banquets, and the rare delights,
With all deare delices and rare delights,
With Erato that doth in loue delite,
But let that same delitious Poet lend
The whiles a most delitious harmony,
There he did find in her delitious boure
That Parents deare from tyrants powre deliuer might.
Till he these wordes to him deliuer might;
Deliuer her fro thence, or with her for you dy.
Deliuer hence out of this dungeon strong,
Deliuer him his owne, ere yet too late,
Her foe deliuer vp into her hand:
Deliuer from the doome of my desart,
For whose deliuera[n]ce she this Prince doth thither guide.
Then meanes I gan deuise for his deliuerance.
And meane of your deliuerance haue beene:
Of his large paines in her deliueraunce
Deliuered it to him, and downe did lay
And streight deliuered to a Faery knight,
As she to me deliuered all that night;
Deliuered vp the Lord of life to die,
As it deliuered was from hond to hond:
Of her faire twins was there deliuered,
But vnto her deliuered Florimell.
Till he to her deliuered had his shield,
Kept, and deliuered me from deadly dread.
Which faire Serene to him deliuered had,
Till that he him deliuered to his punishment.
Deliuered hath into your hands by gift;
Deliuered to her handmayd, that for hyre
Deliuers Phedon, and therefore
And all the moore twixt Eluersham and Dell,
As th'Isle of Delos whylome men report
But with continuall candlelight, which delt
As fresh and fragrant as the floure deluce
A fit false dreame, that can delude the sleepers sent.
But whether dreames delude, or true it were,
Deluded so, gan threaten hellish paine
And halfe in rage, to be deluded thus,
With sight whereof soone cloyd, and long deluded
With which his eyes mote haue deluded beene.
Guyon findes Mammon in a delue,
Which to that shadie delue him brought at last,
In a deepe delue, farre from the vew of day,
It is a darksome delue farre vnder ground,
Where at his feete, with sorrowfull demaine
That was right faire, and modest of demaine,
Well vnderstood, he gan of her demand,
Then gan the Prince, of her for to demand,
Aread in grauer wise, what I demaund of thee.
For to demaund of his renowmed guest:
This thy demaund, ï¿½ Lady, doth reuiue
The God did graunt his daughters deare demaund,
Her to demaund, and chalenge as their rights,
He gently gan him to demaund of all,
Gan to demaund of her some tydings good,
And many things demaund, to which she answer'd light.
Not onely did not his demaund [ap]proue,
Yet could he not their iust demaund deny,
Demaunded, I made plaine and euident,
When he him saw, for no demaunds he staide,
Of his demeane: thenceforth not like a louer,
Of all the vile demeane, and vsage bad,
The whiles that mighty man did her demeane
We should our selues demeane, to low, to hie;
Tho when he long had marked his demeanor,
Of milde demeanure, and rare courtesie,
And in demeanure sober, and in counsell sage.
And loath'd the loose demeanure of that wanton sort.
The diuerse vsage and demeanure daint,
By her sad semblant and demeanure wyse:
And markt her rare demeanure, which him seemed
All his demeasnure from his sight did hyde:
Where Demogorgon in dull darknesse pent,
Till partiall Paris dempt it Venus dew,
He surely dempt, himselfe he thought depriued
Aread what course of you is safest dempt,
With countenance demure, and modest grace,
His countenaunce demure and temperate,
This is the wandring wood, this Errours den,
Her huge long taile her den all ouerspred,
Their dam vpstart, out of her den effraide,
He chose, which he had kept long time in darksome den.
Approch, albe his drowsie den were next;
But like wild beasts lurking in loathsome den,
That euen the wild beast shall dy in starued den.
Suffred, these seuen monethes day in secret den
Since I was brought into this dolefull den;
That ere vnto his hellish den he raught,
Thence forth she past into his dreadfull den,
There let her euer keepe her damned den,
Where she might sit nigh to the den alone,
Ere to his den he backward could recoyle,
And fell Chimï¿½ra in her darkesome den,
And long in darksome Stygian den vpbrought,
All for she Scudamore will not denay.
That with great rage he stoutly doth denay;
The which thy proffred curtesie denayd?
Or loue forbid him, that is life denayd:
Vnworthy they of grace, whom one deniall
Therefore it ought be rendred her without deniall.
Cald Maluen, who entrance none denide:
That wanton Mayd of passage had denide,
Of whom he entrance sought, but was denide,
And let, what euer he desires, be him denide.
Then that his foe should him the field denie,
As one that would confesse, yet faine would it denie.
I may not certes without blame denie;
And entraunce crau'd, which was denied erst.
And ransacke all their dennes from most to least,
And darksom dens, where Titan his face neuer shewes.
Whylest thus she in these hellish dens remayned,
Vnto their hellish dens those theeues them brought;
This doen, into those theeuish dens he went,
By Sanglamort my sword, whose deadly dent
Shew'd all his bodie bare vnto the cruell dent.
Because to yield him loue she doth deny,
The which these Stoicke censours cannot well deny.
Sith then (sayd he) ye both the dead deny,
Of all which, when as she could nought deny,
Yet could he not their iust demaund deny,
List not to hearke, but made this faire denyall;
Would change with me; but I did it denye;
And him she told, her Dame his freedome did denye.
Renew'd her death by timely death denying:
An holy water Sprinckle, dipt in deowe,
That on his shield depainted he did see;
Where cause is none, but to your rest depart.
Doth license him depart at sound of morning droome.
Would safe depart, for all his subtill sleight,
Depart to woods vntoucht, & leaue so proud disdaine?
Let vs soone hence depart. They soone agree;
And euer her desired to depart.
Besought that Damzell suffer him depart,
Which Seuerne now from Logris doth depart:
But let vs hence depart, whilest wether serues and wind.
Such shamefull lusts who loaths not, which depart
That nought but death her dolour mote depart.
To tell the same. I lately did depart
For her depart, that euer man did heare;
His sonne Iulus did from thence depart,
For thy, from that same roome not to depart
Thence to depart for further aide t'enquire:
Thence to depart with glee and gladsome chere.
and soone from her depart.
Fit time for him thence to depart it found,
And wonne her will to suffer him depart;
He seeing her depart, arose vp light,
Yet taking leaue of her, he did depart.
Did enter in, ne would that night depart;
Yet neuer doth from doome of right depart:
And to depart them, if so be he may.
That through the wound his spirit shortly did depart.
And Calidore betooke him to depart,
Whom when her Host saw readie to depart,
Would needes depart, as shall declared be elsewhere.
Departed thence, albe his woundes wide
To beene departed out of Eden lands,
Departed thence with full contended mynd;
That she was gone, departed thence with speed,
Soone as they thence departed were afore,
Departed straight to Proteus therewithall:
That hence so long departed, is but vaine:
Departed from the Castle of the strond,
Departed on his way, as did befall,
So she departed, full of griefe and sdaine,
And so would haue departed on their way.
Departed life, and left vnto them all.
And with them all departes, to tell his great distresse.
The feeble soule departing hence away.
He thence departing gaue for his paines hyre.
